security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation for the Firecrawl MCP tool interface. No executable code, scripts, or network operations are present. The SKILL.md file describes how to call various web scraping modes (scrape, search, map, crawl, extract, check_status) through a structured MCP interface. All static findings are false positives triggered by documentation content being misinterpreted as malicious patterns.

content.value_statement: Manual web scraping requires writing code and handling anti-bot measures. Firecrawl provides a unified interface to scrape websites, search the web, extract structured data, and crawl entire sites with async job support.
actual_capabilities: Scrape single web pages and extract content as markdown or HTML
Search the web for information with result limits
Map website structures by extracting sitemap URLs
Crawl entire websites asynchronously with pagination limits
Extract structured data from URLs using custom prompts and schemas
Check async job status for crawl and extract operations
limitations: Cannot scrape websites with strong anti-bot protection
No JavaScript rendering for dynamic single-page applications
Rate limits depend on the underlying Firecrawl API plan

use_cases.title: Gather research sources
use_cases.description: Extract content from multiple web pages for literature reviews and data collection

use_cases.title: Build content datasets
use_cases.description: Aggregate information from competitor websites or news sources for analysis

use_cases.title: Automate data pipelines
use_cases.description: Extract structured data from web sources to feed into applications and workflows

prompt_templates.title: Scrape a webpage
prompt_templates.prompt: Use Firecrawl to scrape {url} and return the content in markdown format.

prompt_templates.title: Search the web
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for {topic} using Firecrawl and show me the top {number} results.

prompt_templates.title: Map a website
prompt_templates.prompt: Get the sitemap for {url} using Firecrawl map mode to see what pages are available.

prompt_templates.title: Extract structured data
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract structured data from {urls} using this schema: {schema}. Prompt: {instructions}.

output: Key sections: Getting Started, API Reference, Examples
Content preview: Firecrawl makes it easy to scrape websites
Sources include tech news sites and research blogs
Content includes recent breakthroughs and industry updates

best_practices: Use scrape mode for single pages and crawl mode for multiple pages with limits
Check async job status before attempting to retrieve results
Always include URL protocols (http:// or https://) in parameters
anti_patterns: Calling extract with a single URL instead of an array of URLs
Omitting the mode parameter or placing parameters at the top level
Using crawl without a limit on large websites

faq.question: Which modes return immediate results?
faq.answer: Scrape, search, and map are synchronous and return results immediately. Crawl and extract return a job_id for status polling.

faq.question: What formats can I extract content in?
faq.answer: Scrape supports markdown and HTML formats. Markdown is the default and recommended for most use cases.

faq.question: How do I check if my crawl job completed?
faq.answer: Use check_status mode with the job_id returned from crawl or extract operations to retrieve results.

faq.question: Is my scraping data stored anywhere?
faq.answer: Data handling depends on your Firecrawl API provider. Consult their privacy policy for storage details.

faq.question: Why is my crawl returning no results?
faq.answer: Check that the URL is accessible, the domain allows crawling, and you have sufficient API credits or rate limits.

faq.question: How is this different from Tavily search?
faq.answer: Firecrawl focuses on direct website scraping and crawling, while Tavily specializes in search engine queries with optimized results.
